article_title: Robert Nelson: Taking an Ax to Traditional Forest Management
article_text:
Wildfires destroyed an estimated 6,500 square miles of U.S. forest lands in 2013, an area larger than the state of Connecticut. One reason fires blaze through so much land is poor wildfire management from the U.S. Forest Service. But instead of continuing to try to tweak the ossified bureaucracy, we should borrow an idea from public-education reformers: Create "charter forests," like charter schools.

Washington has known about the mismanagement of the Forest Service—whose 35,000 employees are responsible for...

twitter.description: In The Wall Street Journal, Robert Nelson writes that if the charter-school approach works for education, so why not apply it elsewhere?
twitter.title: Taking an Ax to Traditional Forest Management

article_summary:
Washington has known about the mismanagement of the Forest Service—whose 35,000 employees are responsible for...
One reason fires blaze through so much land is poor wildfire management from the U.S. Forest Service.
Wildfires destroyed an estimated 6,500 square miles of U.S. forest lands in 2013, an area larger than the state of Connecticut.
But instead of continuing to try to tweak the ossified bureaucracy, we should borrow an idea from public-education reformers: Create "charter forests," like charter schools.
